title: Ashayet
text:
Ashayet or Ashait was an <a href="ancient%20Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>ian queen consort, a wife of <a href="Mentuhotep%20II">Mentuhotep II</a> in the <a href="Eleventh%20Dynasty%20of%20Egypt">11th Dynasty</a>. Her tomb (DBXI.17) and small decorated chapel were found in <a href="Mentuhotep%20II">Mentuhotep II's</a> <a href="Deir%20el-Bahari">Deir el-Bahari</a> temple complex. The shrine and burial to Ashayet was found along with the tombs of four other women in their twenties and a young girl, <a href="Henhenet">Henhenet</a>, <a href="Kawit%20%28queen%29">Kawit</a>, <a href="Kemsit">Kemsit</a>, <a href="Sadeh%20%28queen%29">Sadeh</a> and <a href="Mayet%20%28ancient%20Egypt%29">Mayet</a>. However, it is likely that there were three other additional shrines that were destroyed in the expansions of Mentuhotep II's burial complex. The nine shrines were built in the <a href="First%20Intermediate%20Period%20of%20Egypt">First Intermediate Period</a>, prior to Mentuhotep II's reunification of Egypt. She and three other women of the six bore queenly titles, and most of them were Priestesses of <a href="Hathor">Hathor</a>. The location of their burial is significant to their titles as Priestesses of <a href="Hathor">Hathor</a> as the cliffs of <a href="Deir%20el-Bahari">Deir el-Bahri</a> were sacred to <a href="Hathor">Hathor</a> from the <a href="Old%20Kingdom%20of%20Egypt">Old Kingdom</a> onwards.
Her titles were: King's Beloved Wife "(ḥmt-nỉswt mrỉỉ.t=f )," King's Sole Ornament "(ẖkr.t-nỉswt wˁtỉ.t)," <a href="Priestess%20of%20Hathor">Priestess of Hathor</a> "(ḥm.t-nṯr ḥwt-ḥrw)," Priestess of Hathor, great of "<a href="Ka%20%28Egyptian%20soul%29">ka</a>"s, foremost in her places "(ḥm.t-nṯr ḥwt-ḥrw wr.t m [k3.w]=s ḫntỉ.t m swt=s)," Priestess of Hathor, great of "ka"s, foremost in her places, Lady of <a href="Dendera">Dendera</a> "(ḥm.t-nṯr ḥwt-ḥrw nb.t ỉwn.t wr.t k3.w=s ḫntỉ.t m swt=s)."
Ashayet's stone sarcophagus (JE 47267) contained a wooden coffin (JE 47355) and a wooden statue was also located in the tomb, they are now found in the <a href="Egyptian%20Museum">Egyptian Museum</a> in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>. Her stone sarcophagus is particularly well known for the exterior relief and painted interior. The painted interior was copied as tempera on paper facsimiles by Charles K. Wilkinson in <a href="Kurna">Gurna</a> in 1926. The facsimiles are now found in the <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum%20of%20Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, New York, but were never published. In the interior decoration two of <a href="Medjay">Medjay</a> women, Federtyt and Mekhenet, are depicted and named as part of Ashayet's household. It has been posited that Ashayet herself was a Nubian elite woman living in Egypt.
